reviews.review_msg: Gives good feedback

Honestly an embarrassment for SFU. Most disorganized, confusing, stressful online class I've ever taken. Super vague criteria. Expects students to dedicate their whole lives to a 3 credit course. Midterm took 9 hours and a lot of crying. Don't take it you value your mental health because it's clear he doesn't value the health of students.

The most vague criteria I've ever experienced in any class. Literally gives one line rubrics and always expects students to go so above and beyond for an A grade. Such limited word limits and limited criteria. Words the assignments so confusing too. Ruined my mental health and gave me several breakdowns.

Taking this course with professor Kaya was one of the most informative courses ive ever taken during my university career. His lecture style is super engaging and he has a great sense of humour. Also great taste in music! Hes an amazing professor and I recommend taking a course with him if you can. He is a very fair grader as long as you work hard.
Developed heart pain and severe anxiety as a result of the stress i got from this class. Had to go to the hospital from the amount of stress i was feeling.

Worst professor ive ever had in my IS degree. Felt so anxious going to every single one of his classes, he is extremely old school. NO electronics, no raising ur hand, dont come 1 minute late, extremely non-leanient with his grading. Has a sense of humour but youll never laugh at any of his jokes because of how depressed you'll feel in that class.

Professor Kaya made sure to get the point across that students often aren't taught to write research papers or write in general until it necessary which I would agree. Lectures are not the most fulfilling and often have to use office hours to get a clearer understanding. Zoom appointments outside office hours were not made an option for me.
No clear criteria, bunch of readings (irrelevant to the course material), never accessible outside class (request for zoom office hour? you'd never get it). please avoid

his lectures are not very engaging and kind of hard to understand. I don't think his marking was bad (he only marked the final), if you follow the criteria you should get a good mark. Marks were based on tutorial participation, a presentation, and the rest were all writing assignments, so it was not too hard to get a good mark if you worked hard.

Nice guy and knows his material well. His lectures are boring but its a politics class so it is expected. Tutorial consisted of 2 presenters a week and small groups answering a question then reporting back to the class. Really tough grading for a first-year class but that is more the TA's. Overall mediocre class.

Lectures were monotone and assignments were graded harder than my 4th year classes. Made up fake SFU protocols so he didnt have to tell us more info about the final. Told us many times that he was trying to prepare us for upper level classes but as someone who has taken many of those, his class was one of the hardest Ive ever done.

His lectures were not clear and easy to understand. Read the textbook! He made funny jokes in lectures which made everyone giggle. I recommend doing the practice questions he assigns for the midterm to do well. All assignments were graded very strictly making it difficult to get more than a pass. This was the hardest IS course I've taken so far.

Professor Kaya is a good professor! He's passionate about what he's teaching and wants you to succeed. I found the lectures interesting, he sometimes goes off on tangents, but pay attention as he makes very good points. I found the class to be difficult, but fair. Make sure to start working on any research paper he assigns ahead of time.

Not the best lecturer, most lectures are based off reading of slides. Found lectures to be sometimes tedious and long however I do respect the amount of breaks he gave us. Tough grader, probably did the worst I've ever done in an IS course.

My favorite prof in IS so far! He's a really nice guy and I enjoyed his lectures so much. The class was very interesting and I learned a lot from him. Lecture slides are not as detailed so you really have to come to class to take full notes. Overall a great experience for me.

Professor is difficult to listen to (in the sense that his presentation is not engaging). Not as detailed in his lectures in comparison to other IS professors/courses. Attending lectures felt irrelevant and a waste of time. When asked questions he did not seem to be fully equipped to answer them. Nice guy, but not the greatest lecturer.

Best teacher in my life, very respectful and very funny. the lecture is kind of bored but he is a good teacher that really care about his students. will take his class again, test is quiet hard but he is very supportive and will take his time talk to students. love him
Awesome and very learned professor.

One of the best profs I've ever had! He is a fantastic teacher; he prepares his classes really well and explains everything making sure everybody understands it. His feedbacks are well detailed, and he is helpful when answering questions in class/office hours. I learned a lot from him, and I'd definitely take another course. Also, he is funny :)
Good in marking and easy course
He's a nice person but a horrible lecturer. The textbook is hard to read. Lecture slides are useless and hard to follow. Too much relies on videos that do not help at all.

Such a great and lovely guy that it makes me sad to say that his teaching is poor. His lectures lose you. Awful slides. Over-reliance on videos - sometimes random television clips. Disconnected tutorials. Weird paper. AWFUL exams with irrelevant questions, absolutely no time and no feedback. Bad textbook and irrelevant readings to top it all off.

Dr. Kaya is an awesome prof! He is funny, organized and is really helpful when answering questions in class or at office hours. He assigns a lot of readings, but you don't need to worry about them too much. Just focus on the readings from the main text and merge it with your lecture notes and you will be good to go!

The class itself was only okay. Like other reviewers, the best part of the class was the videos, but lectures were tough to sit through because he didn't engage the class well. Midterm exam was only 50 minutes but definitely could have used more time and refuses to accept feedback. I won't be taking another class of this professor again.
Good class. Great content. Just do the readings and attend classes and youll be fine. You wont need to study much for the exams.

Serdar did a very good job teaching the labour history of Vancouver and Canada but the rest was just ok... He chose a very boring textbook too. Short documentaries were the best feature of this course. Very eye opening.

Best and the worst prof at the same time. A good teacher. Enthusiastic about what he teaches. Helpful. Lots of feedback too. But he expects too much. Sorry but we can't write academic level papers! Not just yet!
Too much relies on videos. More than half of the lectures are mostly watching videos. Complicated paper. Unclear expectations. Just don't take!

Serdar has a complicated and confusing term paper with the methodology and hypothesis sections. That was too much for a 100 level class. Midterm was not hard but only 55 min long, we needed a bit more time. Go to his office hours, he can help.

Demanding course but you will learn a lot. There are 10 homeworks and each takes time, but to be fair they helped me do better. Serdar's lectures were cool but lab work was more important because you can't possibly do well in this course unless you learn SPSS really really really well. Even the exams are structured around SPSS!

Had this prof for an intro SA stats class and it was the most unpleasant experience of university. Zero feedback on homework, I never knew what I was doing wrong, he was more interested making me complacent with grades I got than helping me do better in the future. Lectures were too easy & didn't prepare well for complexity of homework.

Interesting and engaging lectures - they always opened with a YouTube video!  He helps prepare you for midterms and terms papers, and also gives clear instructions.  **Do not write your paper at the last minute - he will be able to tell.**  Fair, decent, cares about his students, and is available if you have questions.

short essays, lots of reading material, kind/funny prof, would take again. Just keep up with the readings and do not procrastinate your essays. if he smells it was written last minute, you will not do well.

I did not find Serdar helpful when I asked him questions regarding assignments. He was often vague about instructions. I found him to be an inconsistent marker, and that he looked for things in assignments that the questions did not ask for. In POL 241, if you study the Study Guide you will do fine. Don't bother with the textbook.

This prof is decent and knows his material well. He is a nice guy and is approachable for help.  However, the material can be boring sometimes and his monotone voice can really put you to sleep but he can still be funny at times. Textbook is not that important but attending lecture and participation is. Overall, not a bad class but not great either

Was a funny guy at times which I appreciate but also called students out in ways that discouraged people from participating or drawing attention to themselves, which is not cool from a prof. There is a ton of reading but is a fair marker. You have to come to every class and participate in every discussion if you want a good grade.

(Islam & the West) Funny and nice guy! Tries to make 4hr lecture more interesting w videos. Midterm was east, paper was ok, take-home exam was HARD and confusing! You have 5 (FIVE) books to read, 100+ pages each week. If you work hard you will do fine, but be prepared to spend a LOT of time on this course. You will learn something though!!

AMAZING. I can't say enough about how good and up to date his material was and his extremely weird and wonderful sense of humour. This teacher is a must if your taking any courses at SFU. Be prepared to participate, if you miss more than one class, your screwed. Be careful how you frame your questions, you definitely can't get away with saying BS.

Funny prof who teaches an interesting class on Islam. Fun movie reviews are part of the course, and debates/discussions in class are always interesting. Participate in class and do the readings; you should be fine if you do. I do feel like he expects us to read too much (~6 books), which is what we are tested on.
